sub_topic: Determining the degree sequence of a graph.
message_1: Given a graph G with 6 vertices and degree sequence (3,3,2,2,1,1), can you draw the graph G? If not, why not? If yes, provide one possible drawing.
message_2:
Yes, it is possible to draw the graph G with the given degree sequence (3,3,2,2,1,1). Here's one possible drawing:

1. Label the vertices as A, B, C, D, E, and F.
2. Connect vertices A, B, and C to form a triangle (since they have a degree of 3).
3. Connect vertices D and E to vertex A (since they have a degree of 2).
4. Connect vertices F to vertex B (since it has a degree of 1).

The resulting graph will have the following connections:

A - B - C (forming a triangle)
A - D
A - E
B - F

This graph satisfies the given degree sequence.
